animalOfTheDay.name: aardvark
facts: Aardvarks can eat up to 50,000 ants and termites in a single night.
Baby aardvarks are called cubs and stay with their mothers for about 6 months.
Their name comes from Afrikaans meaning 'earth pig' though they're not related to pigs.
They have incredibly strong claws that can dig through concrete.

calendar.name: worm
facts: Earthworms have five hearts and breathe through skin.
Worms regenerate segments; some species regrow heads.
Charles Darwin studied earthworms for 40 years, calling them 'nature's ploughs'.
They improve soil aeration – moving 20 tons of earth per acre annually.

calendar.name: wren
facts: The tiny winter wren weighs less than a nickel but sings loudly.
Wrens roost communally in winter; 60+ birds huddle in nest boxes.
They sing at 10 notes/second – 10x faster than human speech.
Eurasian wrens build dome-shaped nests with side entrances – males build multiple for females to choose.

calendar.name: yak
facts: They grunt instead of mooing; 'yak' mimics their guttural sounds.
Yaks survive at 20,000 ft – lungs and hearts 3x larger than cattle.
Yak milk is rich in butterfat – churned into butter tea in Tibet.
Their dung is dried and burned as fuel in treeless Himalayan regions.

calendar.name: yellowfin tuna
facts: Yellowfins maintain muscle temperature above water via specialized blood vessels.
Yellowfin tuna can reach 50 mph – among the fastest fish.
Their fins glow yellow when excited – a display during feeding frenzies.
They hunt in coordinated schools, herding prey toward the surface.

calendar.name: zebu
facts: Zebus have humps storing fat for drought survival – not water.
Zebu are sacred in India – 330 million gods are said to live in each.
Their loose skin helps dissipate heat in tropical climates.
They sweat insect-repellent oils and tolerate heat better than European cattle.

calendar.name: zonkey
facts: Zonkeys are zebra-donkey hybrids; stripes typically appear only on legs.
Their bray combines zebra whinny and donkey 'hee-haw'.
They inherit donkey calmness with zebra hardiness against diseases.
Zonkeys are sterile due to mismatched chromosomes.

calendar.name: aardvark
facts: Baby aardvarks are called cubs and stay with their mothers for about 6 months.
They have incredibly strong claws that can dig through concrete.
Their name comes from Afrikaans meaning 'earth pig' though they're not related to pigs.
Aardvarks can eat up to 50,000 ants and termites in a single night.

randomAnimals.name: swan
facts: Swans are among the largest flying birds, with some species weighing over 30 pounds.
They mate for life and are known for their graceful courtship displays, including synchronized swimming.
Swans can be aggressive when defending their nests, using their strong wings to strike intruders.
The mute swan is not actually mute; it produces a variety of hisses and grunts.

randomAnimals.name: hippopotamus
facts: Their name comes from the Greek words for 'river horse.'
Hippos are responsible for more human deaths in Africa than lions or crocodiles.
Hippopotamuses are more closely related to whales and dolphins than to other land mammals.
They can hold their breath underwater for up to 5 minutes.

randomAnimals.name: perch
facts: Perch have spiny dorsal fins that help protect them from predators.
They are schooling fish and often hunt in coordinated groups.
They are popular game fish and are found in freshwater lakes and rivers.
Perch can change color slightly to blend in with their surroundings.
